lesson.name: Lesson 2.4: Solving Systems by Elimination, Part 2

page.title: 2.4.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will continue to develop your understanding of solving systems by elimination. You will be given a system that represents the quantities and constraints in a situation and learn to interpret, in context, the solutions to the individual equations and to the system. Ultimately, the context will be used to make sense of the sum of the two equations and why it shares a solution with the equations in the given system.  

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain why adding or subtracting two equations that share a solution results in a new equation that also shares the same solution.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.4.1: Writing and Evaluating New Equations
  • 2.4.2: Adding Two Equations in a System
  • 2.4.2: Self Check
  • 2.4.3: Solving Systems of Linear Equations in Two Variables
  • 2.4.3: Self Check
  • 2.4.4: Solving Systems of Equations Using Real-World Examples 

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 2.4.5: Practice
  • 2.4.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 2.4.1: Writing and Evaluating New Equations
page.contents:
Activity

Look at the following equation: \(50 + 1 = 51\).

1. Perform each of the following operations and answer these questions: What does each resulting equation look like? Is it still a true equation?

a. Add 12 to each side of the equation.


Enter your answers here:

Check your answer:

\(50 + 1 + 12 = 51 + 12\), or \(63 = 63\) (or equivalent). Yes, it is still a true equation.



b. Add \(10 + 2\) to the left side of the equation and 12 to the right side.

Enter your answers here:

Check your answer:

\(50 + 1 + 10 + 2 = 51 + 12\), or \(63 = 63\) (or equivalent). Yes, it is still a true equation.



c. Add the equation \(4 + 3 = 7\) to the equation \(50 + 1 = 51\).

Enter your answers here:

Check your answer:

\(50 + 1 + 4 + 3 = 51 + 7\), or \(58 = 58\) (or equivalent). Yes, it is still a true equation.


2. Write a new equation that, when added to \(50 + 1 = 51\), gives a sum that is also a true equation.

Enter your answers here:

Compare your answers to the sample responses:

  • \(8 + 2 = 10\). Added to the original equation gives: \(50 + 1 + 8 + 2 = 51 + 10\), or \(51 + 10 = 61\), or \(61 = 61\).
  • \(a + a = 2a\). Added to the original equation gives: \(50 + 1 + a + a = 51 + 2a\), or \(51 + 2a = 51 + 2a\).


3. Write a new equation that, when added to \(50 + 1 = 51\), gives a sum that is a false equation.

Enter your answers here:

Compare your answers to the sample responses:

  • \(3 + 2 = 7\). Added to the original equation gives: \(50 + 1 + 3 + 2 = 51 + 7\), or \(56 = 58\), which is false.
  • \(a + 2 = a\). Added to the original equation gives: \(50 + 1 + a + 2 = 51 + a\), or \(53 + a = 51 + a\), which is false.

page.title: 2.4.2: Adding Two Equations in a System
page.contents:
Activity 

A teacher purchased 20 calculators and 10 measuring tapes for her class and paid $495. Later, she realized that she didn’t order enough supplies. She placed another order of 8 of the same calculator and 1 of the same measuring tape and paid $178.50. 


This system represents the constraints in this situation:

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 20c + 10m = 495\\ 8c + m = 178.50 \end{array}\right. \)

1. Discuss with a partner:

a. In this situation, what do the solutions to the first equation mean?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The solutions to \(20c + 10m = 495\) are all possible combinations of unit prices for the two items that make a total of $495 when buying 20 calculators and 10 measuring tapes.

b. In this situation, what do the solutions to the second equation mean?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The solutions to \(8c + m = 178.50\) are all possible combinations of unit prices for the two items that make a total of $178.50 when buying 8 calculators and 1 measuring tape.

c. For each equation, how many possible solutions are there? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Many possible solutions. For example, in the first equation, \(c = 20\) and \(m = 9.50\) would make the equation true, as would \(c = 15\) and \(m = 19.50\).

d. In this situation, what does the solution to the system mean?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The price for a calculator and the price for a measuring tape that would make both equations true (or satisfy both constraints).

2. Find the solution to the system. Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(c = 21.50\) and \(m = 6.50\). (You may solve by graphing or by substitution.)

3. To be reimbursed for the cost of the supplies, the teacher recorded: “Items purchased: 28 calculators and 11 measuring tapes. Amount: $673.50.”

a. Write an equation to represent the relationship between the numbers of calculators and measuring tapes, the prices of those supplies, and the total amount spent.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(28c + 11m = 673.50\)

b. How is this equation related to the first two equations?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It is the sum of the first two equations.

c. In this situation, what do the solutions of this equation mean?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample response: The solutions are all possible combinations of prices for a calculator and for a measuring tape that make a total of $673.50 when 28 calculators and 11 measuring tapes are bought.

d. How many possible solutions does this equation have? How many solutions make sense in this situation? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample response: It has many possible solutions, but only one solution makes sense. The prices of a calculator and of a measuring tape in this equation are the same as those in the other two equations. The new equation simply shows the total numbers of supplies and the total amount paid.

page.title: 2.4.2: Self Check
page.contents:
At a toy store, a family bought 3 toy cars, \(c\), and 2 teddy bears, \(b\), for $46. Later that month, another family bought 7 of the same toy cars, \(c\), and 2 of the same teddy bears, \(b\), for $70. The system represents the situation:

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}3c+2b=46\\\;7c+2b=70\end{array}\right.\)

answer.answer_text: \( 10c+4b=116 \) represents the solutions of the system.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The solution to the system is not a line. \(10c+4b=116\) has infinite solutions, and its graph is a line. The solution to the system is only one of the solutions of \( 10c+4b=116. \)

answer.answer_text: The solution of the system is a solution of \( 10c+4b=116 \).
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: \( 10c+4b=116 \) is the sum of the equations in the system.

answer.answer_text: The solution of the system is not a solution of \( 10c+4b=116 \).
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: \( 10c+4b=116 \) is the sum of the equations in the system. Since the solution makes each equation true, it also makes the sum of the equations true.

answer.answer_text: \( 10c+4b=116 \) is the same line as one of the equations in the system.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: \( 10c+4b=116 \) is the sum of the equations in the system. It is not the same as either line in the system. The solution of the system is a solution of \( 10c+4b=116 \).

page.title: 2.4.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Adding Two Equations in a Real-World Situation

Let’s look at the situation described and write a system of equations.

Paulina went to the pool 8 times and the skating rink 4 times this month. She spent a total of $128 on admission to both places. Last month, she went to the pool 3 times and the skating rink 4 times. Last month she spent $83 on admission to both places.

Let \(p\) represent the cost of the pool and \(s\) represent the cost of the skating rink.

This Month                                  Last Month

\(8p + 4s = 128\)                             \(3p + 4s = 56\)

So, this system represents the constraints in this situation:

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}8p+4s=128\\\;3p+4s=83\end{array}\right.\)

Over both months, she went to the pool 11 times and the skating rink 8 times. She spent a total of \($128 + $83\), or \($211\), over both months.

The equation that represents this total is \(11p + 8s = 211\). Notice this is the equivalent of adding the like terms of the two equations in the system of equations.

Let’s solve the original system and determine if the solution also applies to this new equation.

Using substitution, we find that the solution is \((9, 14)\), or the pool costs $9 and the skating rink costs $14.

Substitute these values into the new equation:

     \(11p + 8s = 211\)

\(11(9) + 8(14) = 211\)

       \(99 + 112 = 211\)

               \(211 = 211\) ✓

Adding the equations together produces a new equation that has the same solution.

Try It: Adding Two Equations in a Real-World Situation

Alicia is a chef for a restaurant. This week, she ordered 32 steaks and 45 chickens. The total cost this week was $840. Last week, she ordered 32 steaks and 24 chickens. The total cost was $672.

Let \(s\) represent the cost of a steak and \(c\) represent the cost of a chicken.

Write a system of equations to represent the constraints given. Then write a new equation that represents the total cost for both weeks.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to write the system and the new equation:

The system of equations to represent this situation is:
\(32s + 45c = 840\)
\(32s + 24c = 672\)

By adding the equations, the new equation is:
\(64s + 69c = 1,512\)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.4.3: Solving Systems of Linear Equations in Two Variables
page.contents:
Activity

Solve each system of equations without graphing and show your reasoning. Then, check your solutions.

System A:

\( A\left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 2x + 3y = 7 \\ -2x + 4y = 14 \end{array}\right. \)

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

A: \( x = -1 \), \( y = 3 \)

\( B\left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 2x + 3y = 7 \\ 3x - 3y = 3 \end{array}\right. \)

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

B: \( x = 2 \), \( y = 1 \)

\(C \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 2x + 3y = 57 \\ 2x + 4y = 9 \end{array}\right. \)

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

C: \( x = -3.5 \), \( y = 4 \)

\(D \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 6x + 9y = 48 \\ 6x - 5y = 20 \end{array}\right. \)

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

D: \( x = 5 \), \( y = 2 \)

Extending your thinking

This system has three equations: 

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 3x + 2y - z = 7 \\ -3x + 5y +2z = -14\\ 3x + y - z = 10 \end{array}\right. \)

1. Add the first two equations to get a new equation.

2. Add the second two equations to get a new equation.

3. Solve the system of your two new equations.

4. What is the solution to the original system of equations?

Enter your answers here:

Check your answer:

1. \( 3y+z=-7 \)
2. \( 2y+z=-4 \)
3. \( y=-3 \), \( z=2 \)
4. \( x=5 \), \( y=-3 \), \( z=2 \)

page.title: 2.4.4: Solving Systems of Equations Using Real-World Examples
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

On a family outing, Marlon bought 5 cups of hot cocoa and 4 pretzels for $18.40. Some of his family members would like a second serving, so he went back to the same food stand and bought another 2 cups of hot cocoa and 4 pretzels for $11.20.

Here is a system of equations that represents the quantities and constraints in this situation.

\( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 5c + 4p = 18.40\\ 2c + 4p = 11.20 \end{array}\right. \)

1. What does the solution to the system, \( (c, p) \), represent in this situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The values of \(c\) and \(p\) represent the price of a cup of hot cocoa and the price of a pretzel that Marlon bought.

2. If we add the second equation to the first equation, we have a new equation: \( 7c + 8p = 29.60 \).

Explain why the same \( (c, p) \) pair that is a solution to the two original equations is also a solution to this new equation.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample explanations:

  1. The new equation shows the total number of cups of hot cocoa and total number of pretzels on one side, and the total amount Marlon spent on the other side. The price of each cup of hot cocoa and the price of each pretzel haven’t changed.

  2. \(2c + 4p\) and 11.20 are equal, so adding \(2c + 4p\) to one side of an equation and adding 11.20 to the other side means adding equal amounts to the two sides of an equation. This keeps the two sides equal. The same values of \(p\) and \(c\) that make the original equations true haven’t changed.
3. Does the equation \( 7c + 8p = 29.60 \) help us solve the original system? If you think so, explain how it helps. If you don’t think so, explain why not and what would help us solve the system.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, it doesn’t help. Sample reasoning: It doesn’t eliminate a variable. What would help is subtracting the second equation from the first to get \(3c = 7.20\). Then we can find \(c\) and solve for \(p\). 

Video: Solving Systems of Equations Using Real-World Examples

Watch the following video to learn more about when addition is useful for solving systems of equations. If you have any questions, play the video again or ask your teacher for clarification.

page.title: 2.4.3: Self Check
page.contents: A mechanic’s garage purchased 8 brake pads and 5 headlight sets for inventory and paid $1,460. Later, the mechanic purchased another order of 6 of the same brake pads and 5 of the same headlight sets and paid $1,220. How much does each part cost?

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The equations representing the constraints are \(8b + 5h = 1,460\) and \(6b + 5h = 1,200\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The equations representing the constraints are \(8b + 5h = 1,460\) and \(6b + 5h = 1,200\). Subtract the equations to get \(2b = 240\) and solve for \(b\). Then solve for \(h\). The answer is brake pads: $120; headlight sets: $100.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The equations representing the constraints are \(8b + 5h = 1,460\) and \(6b + 5h = 1,200\). Subtract the equations to get \(2b = 240\) and solve for \(b\). Then solve for \(h\). The answer is brake pads: $120; headlight sets: $100.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The equations representing the constraints are \(8b + 5h = 1,460\) and \(6b + 5h = 1,200\). Subtract the equations to get \(2b = 240\) and solve for \(b\). Then solve for \(h\). The answer is brake pads: $120; headlight sets: $100.

page.title: 2.4.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solving a System of Equations by Elimination

Let’s reinforce the steps to solve a system of equations using elimination.

Step 1: Write both equations in standard form. If any coefficients are fractions, clear them.

Step 2: Check to see if the coefficients of one variable are opposites. If so, proceed to Step 3. If not, we will cover that in the next lesson.

Step 3: Add the equations resulting from Step 2 to eliminate one variable.

Step 4: Solve for the remaining variable.

Step 5: Substitute the solution from Step 4 into one of the original equations. Then solve for the other variable.

Step 6: Write the solution as an ordered pair.

Step 7: Check that the ordered pair is a solution to both original equations.

 

Example

Let’s look at an example. Solve the following system of equations using elimination:

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}3x-3=-24\\\;-3x+5y=30\end{array}\right.\)

 

Step 1: Write both equations in standard form. If any coefficients are fractions, clear them.

         \(3x - 3y = -24\)

       \(-3x + 5y = 30\)

Step 2: Check to see if the coefficients of one variable are opposites or equivalent.

The coefficients on the \(x\)-variables are opposites. We can add the equations.

Step 3: Add the equations to eliminate one variable.

           \(3x - 3y = -24\)

       \(-3x + 5y = 30\)

               \(2y = 6\)  

Step 4: Solve for the remaining variable.

               \(2y = 6\) 

                 \(y = 3\) 

Step 5: Substitute the solution from Step 4 into one of the original equations. Then solve for the other variable.

       \(3x - 3y = -24\)

    \(3x - 3(3) = -24\)

         \(3x - 9 = -24\)

        \(3x  = -15\)

          \(x  = -5\)

Step 6: Write the solution as an ordered pair.

 

    \((-5, 3)\)

Step 7: Check that the ordered pair is a solution to both original equations.

        \(3x - 3y = -24\)             \(-3x + 5y = 30\)

 \(3(-5) - 3(3) = -24\)    \(-3(-5) + 5(3) = 30\)

        \(-15 - 9 = -24\)               \(15 + 15 = 30\)

             \(-24 = -24\)  ✔               \(30 = 30\) ✔

 

Try It: Solving a System of Equations by Elimination

Solve the following system of equations using elimination:

\(\left\{\begin{array}{l}4x-6y=8\\x+6y=17\end{array}\right.\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to solve this system of equations using elimination:

Step 1: Write both equations in standard form. If any coefficients are fractions, clear them.

         \( 4x - 6y = 8 \)

           \( x + 6y = 17 \)

Step 2: Check to see if the coefficients of one variable are opposites.

The coefficients on the \(y\)-variables are opposites.

Step 3: Add the equations resulting from Step 2 to eliminate one variable.

          \( 4x - 6y = 8 \)

         \(x + 6y = 17 \)

           \( 5x = 25\)

 

Step 4: Solve for the remaining variable.

              \( 5x = 25 \)

                 \( x = 5 \)

Step 5: Substitute the solution from Step 4 into one of the original equations. Then solve for the other variable.

       \( 4x - 6y = 8 \)

    \( 4(5) - 6y = 8 \)

       \( 20 - 6y = 8 \)

           \( -6y = -12 \)

                \( y = 2 \)

Step 6: Write the solution as an ordered pair.

 

    \((5, 2)\)

Step 7: Check that the ordered pair is a solution to both original equations.

        \( 4x - 6y = 8 \)                \( x + 6y = 17 \)

  \(4(5) - 6(2) = 8\)             \( 5 + 6(2) = 17 \)

        \(20 - 12 = 8\)                 \(5 + 12 = 17\)

                  \(8 = 8\)  ✔                  \(17 = 17\) ✔

 

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.4.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–4, add the equations in the system to find a new equation.

1. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 6x - 5y = -1\\ -6x - 3y = -39 \end{array}\right. \)

Multiple choice:

Correct! \(–8y = –40\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(–8y = –40\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 5x - 3y = -1\\ -6x + 3y = -6 \end{array}\right. \)

Multiple choice:

Correct! \(–x = –7\) or \(x = 7\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 2.4.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(–x = –7\) or \(x = 7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 4x - 3y = 3\\ -4x - 10y = 62 \end{array}\right. \)

Multiple choice:

Correct! \(–8x = 65\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(–8x = 65\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. \( -13y = 65 \)

4. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 6x + 16y = -6\\ -6x - 10y = 6 \end{array}\right. \)

Multiple choice:

Correct! \(6y = 0\) or \(y = 0\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 2.4.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(6y = 0\) or \(y = 0\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 5–10, solve each system of equations.


5. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 6x + 27y = -12\\ -6x - 26y = 14 \end{array}\right. \)

Multiple choice:

Correct! \((–11,2)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((–11,2)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 3x + 4y = 8\\ -3x + 6y = 42 \end{array}\right. \)

Multiple choice:

Correct! \((–4,5)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 2.4.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((–4,5)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 5x - 9y = 68\\ -5x + 6y = -47 \end{array}\right. \)

Multiple choice:

Correct! \((1,–7)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((1,–7)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} -3x + 5y = -57\\ 8x - 5y = 77 \end{array}\right. \)

Multiple choice:

Correct! \((4,–9)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 2.4.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((4,–9)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

9. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l} 4x - 2y = -28\\ -7x + 2y = 46 \end{array}\right. \)

Multiple choice:

Correct! \((–6,2)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((–6,2)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

10. \( \left\{ \begin{array}{c l}  -2x + 3y = 23\\ 2x - 6y = -56 \end{array}\right. \)

Multiple choice:

Correct! \((5,11)\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 2.4.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((5,11)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 2.4.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain why adding or subtracting two equations that share a solution results in a new equation that also shares the same solution.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.4.1: Writing and Evaluating New Equations
    • In this activity, you added equivalent values to both sides of an equation to evaluate if the equation was still true. By determining that the equation was still true, you discovered that adding equivalent values to each side of an equation maintains its truth.
  • 2.4.2: Adding Two Equations in a System
    • In this activity, you wrote equations to represent constraints in a real-world situation. You then determined that adding these equations together results in a third equation with the same solution.
  • 2.4.2: Self Check 
  • 2.4.3: Solving Systems of Linear Equations in Two Variables
    • In this activity, you continued solving systems of equations in two variables by using an algebraic method of your own choice. You learned that some systems of equations are more suited to be solved by substitution and others by elimination.
  • 2.4.3: Self Check  
  • 2.4.4: Solving Systems of Equations Using Real-World Examples
    • In this activity, you analyzed a system of equations derived from a real-world situation. You reinforced that to solve a system using elimination by adding, the coefficients of one of the variables must be the same value and have opposite signs. If this is not the case, then no variable is eliminated when the resulting equation is created.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 2.4.5: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
